article:
Mary Elizabeth Truss, known as Liz Truss, is a British politician serving as the Member of Parliament (MP) for South West Norfolk since 2010. She served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and Leader of the Conservative Party from September 2022 to October 2022.

#Early life and education (1975–1996)

Elizabeth Truss was born on July 26, 1975, in Oxford, England, to John Kenneth and Priscilla Mary Truss. Her father is a professor of mathematics and her mother was a nurse and a teacher. Truss was raised in Leeds, West Yorkshire, and later moved to Paisley, Renfrewshire, Scotland, where she attended West Primary School.

Truss was educated at Roundhay School, a comprehensive school in Leeds. She was a member of the school's debating team and was a Liberal Democrat supporter at the time. Truss read philosophy, politics, and economics (PPE) at Merton College, Oxford, where she became the president of the Oxford University Liberal Democrats.

#Career

##Employment and candidatures (1996–2010)

After graduating from Oxford, Truss worked as an economist at Shell and Cable & Wireless. She later became the deputy director of the think tank Reform, where she focused on issues related to education, justice, and the economy.

Truss was a candidate for the Labour Party in the 1996 general election, but she failed to secure the seat. In 2001, she joined the Conservative Party and stood as a candidate for the Greenwich London Borough Council election. Although she was unsuccessful, she continued to work within the party and became the chairman of the Lewisham Deptford Conservative Association.

##Backbencher (2010–2012)

Truss was elected as the MP for South West Norfolk in the 2010 general election, succeeding Christopher Fraser. She served as a member of the Justice Select Committee and the Public Administration Select Committee.

##Education under-secretary (2012–2014)

In September 2012, Truss was appointed as the Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Education and Childcare. She was responsible for implementing the government's education policies, including the expansion of free schools and the improvement of childcare services.

##Environment secretary (2014–2016)

In July 2014, Truss was appointed as the Secretary of State for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs. She played a key role in promoting British food and farming, and she implemented policies to improve animal welfare and reduce pollution.

##Justice secretary and lord chancellor (2016–2017)

In July 2016, Truss was appointed as the Secretary of State for Justice and Lord Chancellor. She was responsible for overseeing the Ministry of Justice and implementing policies to improve the justice system.

##Chief secretary to the Treasury (2017–2019)

In June 2017, Truss was appointed as the Chief Secretary to the Treasury. She played a key role in implementing the government's economic policies, including the control of public spending and the management of the national debt.

##International trade secretary (2019–2021)

In July 2019, Truss was appointed as the Secretary of State for International Trade. She was responsible for promoting British trade and commerce, and she played a key role in negotiating trade agreements with countries around the world.

##Foreign secretary (2021–2022)

In September 2021, Truss was appointed as the Secretary of State for Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Affairs. She was responsible for overseeing British foreign policy and promoting British interests around the world.

###Leadership election (July–September 2022)

In July 2022, Truss announced her candidacy for the leadership of the Conservative Party and the position of Prime Minister. She won the election in September 2022, defeating Rishi Sunak in the final round of voting.

#Premiership (2022)

##Cabinet and death of Elizabeth II

Truss formed her cabinet on September 6, 2022, and she appointed Kwasi Kwarteng as her Chancellor of the Exchequer. On September 8, 2022, Queen Elizabeth II passed away, and Truss became the first Prime Minister to serve under King Charles III.

##Domestic policies and mini-budget

Truss's government implemented a series of domestic policies, including the introduction of a cap on energy prices and the abolition of the top rate of income tax. On September 23, 2022, Kwarteng announced a mini-budget, which included plans to reduce taxes and increase spending.

##Government crisis and resignation

The mini-budget was widely criticized, and it sparked a crisis in the financial markets. On October 14, 2022, Truss announced her resignation as Prime Minister and Leader of the Conservative Party, and she was succeeded by Rishi Sunak.

#Post-premiership (2022–present)

Truss remains a member of the House of Commons and serves as the MP for South West Norfolk. She has continued to speak out on issues related to economics and foreign policy.

#Political positions

##Domestic issues

Truss has advocated for a range of domestic policies, including the reduction of taxes, the improvement of education, and the promotion of British industry. She has also supported the expansion of free schools and the improvement of childcare services.

##Foreign policy

Truss has been a strong supporter of British foreign policy, and she has advocated for the promotion of British interests around the world. She has also supported the strengthening of NATO and the improvement of relations with countries in the Asia-Pacific region.

Indonesia at the 2022 Asian Games

The 2022 Asian Games, officially known as the XIX Asiad, is a multi-sport event that will be held in Hangzhou, China, from September 10 to September 25, 2022. Indonesia is one of the participating nations in the Games. The country has been participating in the Asian Games since the inaugural edition in 1951.

#Background

##Administration

The Indonesian Asian Games contingent is administered by the Indonesian Olympic Committee (KOI). The committee is responsible for selecting and preparing the athletes, officials, and support staff for the Games.

##Flag bearers

The flag bearers for the Indonesian contingent at the opening ceremony of the 2022 Asian Games are yet to be announced.

##Broadcasters

The 2022 Asian Games will be broadcast in Indonesia by TVRI, SCTV, and Indosiar.

article:
Forbidden Door (2022)

Forbidden Door was a professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event produced by All Elite Wrestling (AEW) and New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW). The event took place on June 26, 2022, at the United Center in Chicago, Illinois. It was the first-ever PPV event co-produced by AEW and NJPW, marking a significant milestone in the collaboration between the two promotions.

# Production

## Background

The concept of Forbidden Door was first announced in November 2021, during the AEW Full Gear event. AEW President Tony Khan revealed that the promotion was working on a joint project with NJPW, which would feature a series of matches between wrestlers from both promotions. The event was officially announced in February 2022, with the United Center in Chicago selected as the venue.

## Storylines

The event featured a mix of storyline-driven matches and dream bouts between AEW and NJPW wrestlers. The main event of the evening saw Jon Moxley face Hiroshi Tanahashi for the Interim AEW World Championship, while the co-main event featured Jay White defending his IWGP United States Heavyweight Championship against Kazuchika Okada, Adam Page, and Adam Cole in a four-way match.

Other notable matches included the Young Bucks facing the team of El Phantasmo and Tomohiro Ishii, as well as the in-ring debut of Will Ospreay, who faced Orange Cassidy. The event also featured the inaugural match for the AEW All-Atlantic Championship, which saw Pac, Miro, and Malakai Black compete for the title.

# Event

## The Buy-In

The event began with a pre-show, known as The Buy-In, which featured a series of matches and segments. The Buy-In was streamed live on AEW's social media channels and YouTube.

## Preliminary matches

The main card began with a match between Keith Lee and Shinjiro Otani, which Lee won with a Spirit Bomb. The next match saw Lance Archer face Nick Comoroto, which Archer won with a Blackout.

The Young Bucks then faced El Phantasmo and Tomohiro Ishii in a tag team match, which the Bucks won with a BTE Trigger. The match was notable for its high-flying moves and near-falls, showcasing the athleticism and chemistry of all four competitors.

The next match saw Will Ospreay make his AEW debut against Orange Cassidy, which Ospreay won with a Stormbreaker. The match was a showcase of Ospreay's aerial abilities and Cassidy's laid-back style.

## Main event

The main event of the evening saw Jon Moxley face Hiroshi Tanahashi for the Interim AEW World Championship. The match was a highly anticipated bout between two of the best wrestlers in the world, with Moxley's intensity and Tanahashi's experience on full display.

In the end, Moxley emerged victorious with a Paradigm Shift, winning the Interim AEW World Championship. The match was met with a standing ovation from the crowd, who were on their feet for the entirety of the bout.

# Aftermath

Forbidden Door was widely praised by fans and critics alike, with many considering it one of the best PPV events of the year. The event marked a successful collaboration between AEW and NJPW, and set the stage for future joint events between the two promotions.

The event also had significant implications for AEW's ongoing storylines, particularly with regards to the Interim AEW World Championship. Moxley's win set him up for a future match against CM Punk, who was announced as the next challenger for the title.

# Results

## AEW Interim World Championship Eliminator Series bracket

* Jon Moxley defeated Hiroshi Tanahashi in the final match of the eliminator series to win the Interim AEW World Championship.

## AEW All-Atlantic Championship inaugural tournament bracket

* Pac defeated Miro and Malakai Black in the final match of the tournament to become the inaugural AEW All-Atlantic Champion.

article:
Taylor Lorenz

Taylor Lorenz is an American journalist and writer, known for her work covering technology, social media, and online culture. She has written for several prominent publications, including The Washington Post and The New York Times, and has become a prominent voice in the conversation around the intersection of technology and society.

#Early life and education

Taylor Lorenz was born and raised in New York City. She developed an interest in journalism at a young age and pursued a degree in English and Creative Writing from the University of Colorado Boulder. After college, Lorenz moved to New York City to pursue a career in writing and journalism.

#Career

Lorenz began her career as a writer and editor for several small publications and websites. She quickly developed a focus on technology and social media, and began writing for larger outlets, including The Washington Post and The New York Times.

##The Washington Post

In 2018, Lorenz joined The Washington Post as a technology reporter. During her time at the Post, she covered a wide range of topics related to technology and social media, including the rise of TikTok, the impact of social media on mental health, and the growing concern around online harassment. Her reporting was widely praised, and she became a prominent voice in the conversation around technology and society.

##Independent journalism

In 2020, Lorenz left The Washington Post to pursue independent journalism. She began writing for several publications, including The New York Times and Harper's Bazaar, and launched her own newsletter, which focused on technology, social media, and online culture. Through her independent work, Lorenz has continued to cover the intersection of technology and society, and has become known for her insightful and nuanced reporting.

#Harassment and coordinated attacks

Lorenz has been the subject of harassment and coordinated attacks online. In 2020, she was targeted by a group of online trolls, who sent her threatening messages and attempted to discredit her reporting. The incident highlighted the growing concern around online harassment, and the need for greater protections for journalists and writers.

#Personal life

Lorenz is active on social media, where she has a large following. She is known for her engaging and insightful posts, which often focus on technology, social media, and online culture. In her free time, Lorenz enjoys hiking and spending time with her family.

#Selected publications

* "The Meme Generation" (The New York Times, 2020)
* "The Rise of TikTok" (The Washington Post, 2019)
* "The Impact of Social Media on Mental Health" (The Washington Post, 2019)
* "The Growing Concern Around Online Harassment" (Harper's Bazaar, 2020)

#Notes

article:
Bigg Boss (Malayalam TV series) Season 4

Bigg Boss Malayalam Season 4 is the fourth season of the Malayalam-language version of the Indian reality television series Bigg Boss. The show premiered on 27 March 2022 on Asianet and was hosted by Mohanlal. The season concluded on 3 July 2022.

#Production

The show was produced by Endemol Shine India and was broadcast on Asianet. The show was hosted by Mohanlal, who also hosted the previous three seasons. The show was filmed at a custom-built set in Mumbai, Maharashtra. The season consisted of 100 days, during which the contestants, known as "housemates," lived together in a specially designed house with cameras and microphones recording their every move.

#Housemates status

The housemates were a diverse group of 17 people from different walks of life. They were from different professions, ages, and backgrounds. The contestants were divided into two groups: celebrities and commoners. The celebrities included actors, singers, and models, while the commoners were ordinary people who were not part of the entertainment industry.

The 2023 Canadian wildfires were a series of devastating wildfires that burned across Canada throughout the spring and summer of 2023. # Background

Canada is prone to wildfires, particularly in the western provinces where forests are dense and dry conditions are common. In recent years, the country has experienced an increase in wildfires, with 2023 being one of the worst years on record. The Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre reported that there were over 2,000 wildfires burning across the country at the peak of the season, with many more smaller fires burning in remote areas.

North Kosovo Crisis (2022–2024)

The North Kosovo crisis, also known as the Kosovo-Serbia crisis, was a period of heightened tensions and unrest between Kosovo and Serbia that began in 2022 and continued into 2024. The crisis primarily affected the northern region of Kosovo, where a significant ethnic Serb population resides. The tensions centered on issues of governance, security, and ethnic relations, leading to a series of protests, clashes, and diplomatic efforts to resolve the situation.

# Background

Kosovo declared independence from Serbia in 2008, but the move was not recognized by Serbia or some other countries. The northern part of Kosovo, which borders Serbia, has a majority ethnic Serb population and has historically been a source of tension between the two countries. In the years leading up to the crisis, there were ongoing efforts to normalize relations between Kosovo and Serbia, but progress was slow.

The region is rich in natural resources, including coal, lead, and zinc, which has contributed to the economic significance of the area. However, the region's economy has struggled, with high levels of unemployment and poverty. The lack of economic opportunities and the presence of ethnic tensions have created a volatile environment in which the crisis unfolded.

# Timeline

## 2022

### July

The crisis began in July 2022, when Kosovo authorities launched a crackdown on smuggling and organized crime in the north. The operation, which involved the deployment of Kosovo police and special forces, aimed to dismantle smuggling networks and assert Kosovo's authority in the region. However, the move was met with resistance from ethnic Serb communities, who saw the operation as an attempt to exert control over their territory.

### August

Tensions escalated in August 2022, when a group of ethnic Serb protesters blocked roads and border crossings in the north. The protesters, who were demanding greater autonomy and recognition of their rights, clashed with Kosovo police, resulting in several injuries and arrests.

### September

In September 2022, the Kosovo government announced plans to introduce a new license plate system, which would require vehicles in the north to display Kosovo plates. The move was seen as an attempt to assert Kosovo's authority and sovereignty over the region, but it was met with fierce resistance from ethnic Serb communities, who saw the move as an attack on their identity and rights.

### October

The situation deteriorated further in October 2022, when a group of ethnic Serb protesters attacked a Kosovo police station in the north. The attack, which resulted in several injuries and damage to property, was condemned by Kosovo authorities and international organizations.

### November

In November 2022, the Kosovo government imposed a curfew in the north, citing concerns about public safety and security. The move was met with widespread criticism from ethnic Serb communities, who saw the curfew as an attempt to restrict their freedom of movement and assembly.

### December

The year ended with a series of protests and clashes in the north, as ethnic Serb communities continued to demand greater autonomy and recognition of their rights. The situation remained volatile, with both sides accusing each other of aggression and provocation.

## 2023

### January

The new year began with a series of diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis. The European Union and the United States launched a joint initiative to facilitate dialogue between Kosovo and Serbia, but progress was slow.

### February

In February 2023, the Kosovo government announced plans to establish a new municipality in the north, which would be governed by ethnic Serb leaders. The move was seen as an attempt to address the concerns of ethnic Serb communities and promote greater autonomy and self-governance.

### March

However, the move was met with opposition from some Kosovo politicians, who saw the creation of a new municipality as a threat to Kosovo's sovereignty and territorial integrity.

### April

The situation remained tense in April 2023, with a series of protests and clashes in the north. The Kosovo government accused Serbia of interfering in the region and promoting separatism, while Serbia accused Kosovo of suppressing the rights of ethnic Serb communities.

### May

In May 2023, the European Union launched a new initiative to facilitate dialogue between Kosovo and Serbia. The initiative, which involved the deployment of EU diplomats and experts, aimed to promote greater cooperation and understanding between the two sides.

### June

However, the initiative was met with skepticism by some Kosovo politicians, who saw the EU's involvement as an attempt to impose a solution on Kosovo.

### July

The situation deteriorated further in July 2023, when a group of ethnic Serb protesters attacked a Kosovo police station in the north. The attack, which resulted in several injuries and damage to property, was condemned by Kosovo authorities and international organizations.

### September

In September 2023, the Kosovo government announced plans to hold local elections in the north. The move was seen as an attempt to promote greater democracy and self-governance in the region, but it was met with opposition from some ethnic Serb communities, who saw the elections as an attempt to exert control over their territory.

### October

The situation remained tense in October 2023, with a series of protests and clashes in the north. The Kosovo government accused Serbia of interfering in the region and promoting separatism, while Serbia accused Kosovo of suppressing the rights of ethnic Serb communities.

### November

In November 2023, the European Union launched a new initiative to facilitate dialogue between Kosovo and Serbia. The initiative, which involved the deployment of EU diplomats and experts, aimed to promote greater cooperation and understanding between the two sides.

### December

The year ended with a series of protests and clashes in the north, as ethnic Serb communities continued to demand greater autonomy and recognition of their rights. The situation remained volatile, with both sides accusing each other of aggression and provocation.

## 2024

### February

The new year began with a series of diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis. The United States launched a new initiative to facilitate dialogue between Kosovo and Serbia, but progress was slow.

### August

The situation remained tense in August 2024, with a series of protests and clashes in the north. The Kosovo government accused Serbia of interfering in the region and promoting separatism, while Serbia accused Kosovo of suppressing the rights of ethnic Serb communities.

# Reactions

The North Kosovo crisis has been widely condemned by international organizations and countries, including the European Union, the United States, and the United Nations. The crisis has been seen as a major threat to regional stability and security, and there have been calls for greater dialogue and cooperation between Kosovo and Serbia.

2022 European Women's Handball Championship

The 2022 European Women's Handball Championship was the 15th edition of the European Women's Handball Championship, organized by the European Handball Federation (EHF). The tournament took place in Slovenia, North Macedonia, and Montenegro from November 4 to 20, 2022.

# Bidding process

The bidding process for the 2022 European Women's Handball Championship began in 2018, with several countries expressing interest in hosting the tournament.

## Bidding timeline

* June 2018: The EHF announced the bidding process for the 2022 European Women's Handball Championship.
* September 2018: The deadline for submitting bids was set for November 2018.
* November 2018: The EHF received bids from several countries, including Slovenia, North Macedonia, Montenegro, and others.
* January 2019: The EHF evaluated the bids and shortlisted the candidates.
* June 2019: The EHF announced the winning bid, with Slovenia, North Macedonia, and Montenegro selected as co-hosts.

## Bids

* Slovenia
* North Macedonia

# Venues

The 2022 European Women's Handball Championship was played in several venues across Slovenia, North Macedonia, and Montenegro. The venues included:

* Ljubljana, Slovenia: Arena Stožice

The Battle of Bakhmut is an ongoing military conflict in the city of Bakhmut, Donetsk Oblast, Ukraine, between Ukrainian government forces and Russian-backed separatists, with Russian military involvement. The battle has been one of the most intense and prolonged engagements of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, with both sides suffering significant casualties.

Norway at the 2022 Winter Olympics

Norway competed at the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing, China, from 4 to 20 February 2022. The Norwegian team consisted of 84 athletes competing in 9 out of 15 sports. Norway won a total of 37 medals, including 16 gold medals, 8 silver medals, and 13 bronze medals, making it the second most successful country in the overall medal table.

article:
Angela Lansbury

Angela Lansbury is a British-American actress, singer, and producer whose career spans over seven decades. Born on October 16, 1925, in Regent's Park, London, Lansbury has established herself as one of the most respected and beloved actresses of her generation. With a career that has taken her from the stage to the screen, Lansbury has captivated audiences with her versatility, range, and iconic performances.

#Early life and career beginnings

##Childhood: 1925–1942

Angela Lansbury was born to Edgar Lansbury, a timber merchant, and Moyna MacGill, an actress. She was the first of two daughters, with her younger sister Isolde being born in 1928. Lansbury's early life was marked by the influence of her mother's acting career, with the family often attending theatre performances and film screenings. In 1939, Lansbury's father passed away, and her mother moved the family to the United States to escape the onset of World War II.

##Career breakthrough: 1942–1945

Lansbury began her acting career at the age of 16, landing a role in the 1942 film "Gaslight" opposite Ingrid Bergman. Her performance earned her an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actress, making her one of the youngest nominees in the category at the time. This breakthrough role led to a contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM), where she went on to appear in a string of films throughout the 1940s.

##Later MGM films: 1945–1951

During her time at MGM, Lansbury appeared in a range of films, including "The Picture of Dorian Gray" (1945), "The Harvey Girls" (1946), and "State of the Union" (1948). Her performances were well-received, but she began to feel typecast in supporting roles. In the early 1950s, Lansbury decided to leave MGM and explore other opportunities, both on stage and screen.

#Mid career

##The Manchurian Candidate and minor roles: 1952–1965

Lansbury's departure from MGM led to a period of relative obscurity, with the actress appearing in a string of minor roles on stage and screen. However, her performance as the manipulative Mrs. Iselin in John Frankenheimer's "The Manchurian Candidate" (1962) earned her critical acclaim and an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actress. This marked a turning point in Lansbury's career, as she began to be recognized for her versatility and range.

##Mame and theatrical stardom: 1966–1969

In 1966, Lansbury took on the title role in the Broadway musical "Mame," earning widespread critical acclaim and a Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical. Her performance marked a new era in her career, as she transitioned from film to stage and established herself as a leading lady of the theatre. Lansbury's success in "Mame" led to a string of theatrical roles, including "Dear World" (1969) and "Gypsy" (1974).

##Ireland and Gypsy: 1970–1978

In the early 1970s, Lansbury moved to Ireland, where she lived for several years and continued to work on stage and screen. Her performance as Mama Rose in the 1974 Broadway revival of "Gypsy" earned her a second Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical. During this period, Lansbury also appeared in a range of films, including "Death on the Nile" (1978) and "The Mirror Crack'd" (1980).

##Sweeney Todd and continued cinematic work: 1979–1984

Lansbury's success on stage continued with her performance as Mrs. Lovett in the 1979 Broadway production of "Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street." Her portrayal of the eccentric and calculating Mrs. Lovett earned her a third Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical. During this period, Lansbury also continued to appear in a range of films, including "The Last Unicorn" (1982) and "Little Gloria... Happy at Last" (1982).

#Global fame

##Murder, She Wrote: 1984–2003

In 1984, Lansbury took on the role of Jessica Fletcher in the CBS television series "Murder, She Wrote." The show, which ran for 12 seasons, became a global phenomenon, with Lansbury's performance as the clever and resourceful mystery writer earning her widespread critical acclaim and a range of awards. During her time on the show, Lansbury became a household name, and her iconic portrayal of Jessica Fletcher cemented her status as a beloved and respected actress.

##Final years: 2003–2022

Following the conclusion of "Murder, She Wrote," Lansbury continued to work on stage and screen, appearing in a range of films and television shows, including "Nanny McPhee" (2005), "Mary Poppins Returns" (2018), and "Little Women" (2019). In 2022, Lansbury passed away at the age of 96, leaving behind a legacy as one of the most beloved and respected actresses of her generation.

#Personal life

Lansbury was married twice, first to Richard Cromwell from 1945 until their divorce in 1946, and then to Peter Shaw from 1949 until his death in 2003. She had two children, Anthony and Deirdre, and lived for many years in Ireland and Los Angeles.

#Honours and legacy

Throughout her career, Lansbury received numerous awards and honors for her performances, including three Tony Awards, six Golden Globe Awards, and an Academy Award nomination. She was also recognized for her contributions to the arts, with a Kennedy Center Honor in 2000 and a Disney Legends award in 1995. Lansbury's legacy as a beloved and respected actress continues to endure, with her iconic performances remaining a source of inspiration and delight for audiences around the world.

#Publications

* "Balancing Act: A Biography of Angela Lansbury" by Martin Gottfried (1999)

#Notes

2022 Asian Men's Volleyball Cup

The 2022 Asian Men's Volleyball Cup is an international volleyball tournament organized by the Asian Volleyball Confederation (AVC). The sixth edition of the tournament, it took place in Taipei, Taiwan from August 7 to 14, 2022. The event featured 11 teams from across Asia, competing in a round-robin format followed by a classification and final round.

# Host selection

Taipei, Taiwan was chosen as the host city for the 2022 Asian Men's Volleyball Cup. The decision was made by the AVC in 2021, with Taipei being a popular destination for international volleyball events.

# Qualification

article:
Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt, also known as the Hessian State Museum in Darmstadt, is a museum located in Darmstadt, Germany. It is one of the most important cultural institutions in the state of Hesse and a significant museum in Germany.

#History

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt has a long and rich history dating back to the 19th century. The museum was founded in 1820 by Grand Duke Louis I of Hesse as a "Großherzogliche Sammlung" (Grand Ducal Collection). The collection was initially housed in the Darmstadt Palace and consisted of artworks and artifacts from the grand ducal family's private collections.

Over the years, the collection grew significantly, and the museum became a central institution for the preservation and promotion of Hessian cultural heritage. In 1877, the museum was moved to its current location on Friedensplatz in Darmstadt. The building was designed by the architect Alfred Messel, who also designed the Pergamon Museum in Berlin.

In the early 20th century, the museum underwent significant changes. During World War I, the museum's collections were relocated to safety, and the building was converted into a military hospital. After the war, the museum was reopened, and the collections were reassembled.

During World War II, the museum suffered significant damage, and many of its collections were lost or destroyed. The building was heavily bombed, and the museum's collections were scattered throughout the city. After the war, the museum was rebuilt, and the collections were reassembled.

#Building

##Location

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt is located on Friedensplatz in the heart of Darmstadt. The building is situated in a prominent location, surrounded by other important cultural institutions, including the Darmstadt Palace and the Staatstheater Darmstadt.

##Renovations and extensions

Over the years, the museum has undergone several renovations and extensions. In the 1950s and 1960s, the museum was renovated to repair damage from World War II. In the 1970s and 1980s, the museum underwent significant expansions, including the addition of new exhibition spaces and a modern museum restaurant.

In 2006, the museum underwent a major renovation, which included the restoration of the original facade and the modernization of the exhibition spaces. The renovation was designed by the architect Volker Staab and took several years to complete.

#Collections

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt has a diverse collection of artworks and artifacts from the state of Hesse. The collection includes:

* Artworks from the Middle Ages to the present day, including paintings, sculptures, and prints
* Archaeological artifacts from the prehistoric period to the Middle Ages
* Ethnographic objects from around the world
* Historical artifacts from the state of Hesse, including furniture, textiles, and decorative arts
* Scientific instruments and equipment from the 18th and 19th centuries

The museum's collection is particularly strong in the areas of Hessian art and cultural history. The museum has an impressive collection of artworks by Hessian artists, including paintings by the 19th-century artist Ludwig Emil Grimm.

#Gallery

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt has several permanent galleries, including:

* The Hessian Art Gallery, which features artworks from the Middle Ages to the present day
* The Archaeological Gallery, which features artifacts from the prehistoric period to the Middle Ages
* The Ethnographic Gallery, which features objects from around the world
* The Historical Gallery, which features artifacts from the state of Hesse

The museum also has several temporary exhibition spaces, which host changing exhibitions throughout the year.

#Special exhibitions

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt hosts several special exhibitions throughout the year. These exhibitions are often organized in collaboration with other museums and cultural institutions.

Some recent special exhibitions at the museum include:

* "Ludwig Emil Grimm: A Hessian Artist" (2019)
* "The Art of the Middle Ages in Hesse" (2018)
* "The Archaeology of the Rhine-Main Region" (2017)
* "The Ethnographic Collection of the Hessisches Landesmuseum" (2016)

#Controversies

The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt has been involved in several controversies over the years. One of the most significant controversies was the museum's decision to return several artifacts to their countries of origin. The museum had acquired these artifacts during the colonial period, and they were later deemed to be cultural property that should be returned to their countries of origin.

The museum has also been criticized for its handling of sensitive topics, such as the legacy of National Socialism in Hesse. The museum has been accused of not doing enough to address the state's complicity in the Holocaust.

#Films

* "The Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt" (2019), a documentary film about the museum's history and collections
* "Art and Culture in Hesse" (2018), a documentary film about the cultural institutions of Hesse, including the Hessisches Landesmuseum Darmstadt

2023 World Men's Curling Championship

The 2023 World Men's Curling Championship was the 65th edition of the World Men's Curling Championship, held from April 1 to 9, 2023, at the Basel Exhibition Centre in Basel, Switzerland. The event was organized by the World Curling Federation (WCF) and featured 13 national teams competing in a round-robin format, followed by playoffs.

# Summary

The 2023 World Men's Curling Championship was won by the host team from Switzerland, skipped by Yannick Schwaller, who defeated the team from Canada, skipped by Brad Gushue, in the final. It was Switzerland's 4th World Men's Curling Championship title. The bronze medal was won by the team from Scotland, skipped by Bruce Mouat.

# Qualification

## Selection of national teams

The 13 teams that competed in the 2023 World Men's Curling Championship qualified through various means. The top 7 teams from the 2022 World Men's Curling Championship, the top 2 teams from the 2022 European Curling Championships, the top team from the 2022 Pacific-Asia Curling Championships, and the top team from the 2022 Americas Challenge qualified directly for the event. The remaining 2 teams were determined through a qualification tournament held in January 2023.

article:
Alexander Suvorov
================

Alexander Vasilyevich Suvorov was a Russian military leader, considered one of the greatest generals in Russian history. He is known for his exceptional military skills, innovative tactics, and unwavering dedication to his country. Suvorov's remarkable career spanned over five decades, during which he fought in numerous wars, conquered vast territories, and earned the respect and admiration of his contemporaries.

Early Life
-----------

### Origins

Alexander Suvorov was born on November 13, 1730, in Moscow, Russia, to a noble family of modest means. His father, Vasily Ivanovich Suvorov, was a military officer who served in the Imperial Russian Army, and his mother, Avdotya Fedorovna Mansurova, was a member of the minor nobility.

### Childhood

Suvorov's childhood was marked by a strong interest in military affairs, which was encouraged by his father. He spent much of his youth reading military texts, practicing martial skills, and participating in mock battles with his friends. Suvorov's parents recognized his passion and talent for warfare and decided to enroll him in the Imperial Russian Army at the age of 12.

Early Career
------------

### First Military Experience

Suvorov's first military experience was in the Imperial Russian Army, where he served as a cadet in the Semenovsky Regiment. He quickly demonstrated his aptitude for military life and was promoted to ensign in 1748.

### 1761

In 1761, Suvorov was appointed to the rank of captain and participated in the Seven Years' War, fighting against the Prussian army. During this campaign, he distinguished himself as a brave and resourceful officer, earning the respect of his superiors and comrades.

### Freemasonry, Berlin

In 1762, Suvorov traveled to Berlin, where he became acquainted with the principles of Freemasonry. He was deeply influenced by the ideals of the Masonic movement, which emphasized the importance of brotherhood, morality, and self-improvement. In the 1990s and 2000s, Birkin appeared in a range of films and television productions, including "A Soldier's Daughter Never Cries" (1998) and "Merci Docteur Rey" (2002). She also released several albums, including "Fictions" (1996) and "Arabesque" (2002).

article:
**Mount Omurga**

Mount Omurga is a mountain peak located in the Crimean Mountains, on the Crimean Peninsula in Ukraine. It is one of the highest peaks in the region and offers breathtaking views of the surrounding landscape. In this article, we will delve into the geography, geology, flora and fauna, climate, and human activities related to Mount Omurga.

**# Geography**

Mount Omurga is situated in the central part of the Crimean Mountains, approximately 30 kilometers (19 miles) south of the city of Simferopol. The mountain peak is part of the Babugan-Yaila mountain range, which stretches for about 40 kilometers (25 miles) in a northwest-southeast direction. Mount Omurga has an elevation of 1,264 meters (4,147 feet) above sea level, making it one of the highest peaks in the Crimean Mountains.

## Location and Boundaries

Mount Omurga is bordered by several valleys and ridges, including the Salgir River valley to the north and the Angara River valley to the south. The mountain peak is surrounded by several smaller hills and peaks, including the Hora-Kastel peak to the east and the Babugan peak to the west. The boundaries of Mount Omurga are not strictly defined, as the mountain peak is part of a larger mountain range.

## Topography

The topography of Mount Omurga is characterized by a combination of gentle slopes and steep cliffs. The mountain peak is formed from a series of limestone and dolomite rocks, which have been eroded over time by wind and water. The summit of the mountain is relatively flat, with a series of rocky outcrops and scree slopes. The slopes of the mountain are covered in a mixture of grasses, shrubs, and trees, including oak, beech, and pine.

**# Geology**

The geology of Mount Omurga is complex and varied, with a range of rocks and minerals present in the area. The mountain peak is formed from a series of limestone and dolomite rocks, which date back to the Jurassic period. These rocks have been eroded over time by wind and water, resulting in the formation of a range of landforms, including caves, arches, and rock pillars.

## Rock Formations

The rock formations on Mount Omurga are characterized by a combination of limestone, dolomite, and sandstone. The limestone rocks are formed from the remains of ancient marine organisms, including coral and shellfish. The dolomite rocks are formed from the alteration of limestone rocks, resulting in a range of minerals, including calcite and dolomite. The sandstone rocks are formed from the erosion of older rocks, resulting in a range of minerals, including quartz and feldspar.

## Mineral Resources

Mount Omurga is rich in mineral resources, including copper, iron, and manganese. The copper deposits are found in the form of malachite and azurite, which are formed from the alteration of limestone rocks. The iron deposits are found in the form of hematite and magnetite, which are formed from the alteration of dolomite rocks. The manganese deposits are found in the form of pyrolusite and rhodochrosite, which are formed from the alteration of limestone rocks.

**# Flora and Fauna**

The flora and fauna on Mount Omurga are diverse and varied, with a range of plant and animal species present in the area. The mountain peak is home to a range of trees, including oak, beech, and pine, as well as a range of shrubs and grasses.

The shrubs include a range of species, including juniper and rosemary. The grasses include a range of species, including feather grass and blue grass.

## Animal Species

The animal species on Mount Omurga include a range of mammals, birds, and reptiles. The mammals include a range of species, including deer, wild boar, and rabbit. The birds include a range of species, including eagle, hawk, and falcon. The reptiles include a range of species, including snake, lizard, and tortoise.

**# Climate**

The climate on Mount Omurga is temperate, with a range of weather conditions present throughout the year. The mountain peak is subject to a range of weather patterns, including wind, rain, and snow.

## Temperature

The temperature on Mount Omurga varies throughout the year, with warm summers and cold winters. The average temperature in the summer is around 20°C (68°F), while the average temperature in the winter is around 0°C (32°F).

## Precipitation

The precipitation on Mount Omurga is significant, with a range of rainfall and snowfall present throughout the year. The average annual rainfall is around 600 mm (24 in), while the average annual snowfall is around 100 cm (39 in).

**# Human Activities**

Mount Omurga has been home to a range of human activities, including hiking, climbing, and skiing. The mountain peak is a popular destination for tourists, with a range of amenities and services available, including hotels, restaurants, and shops.

## Hiking and Climbing

The hiking and climbing routes on Mount Omurga are varied and challenging, with a range of routes available for different levels of experience. The mountain peak is home to a range of rock formations, including caves, arches, and rock pillars, which offer a range of climbing opportunities.

The mountain peak is home to a range of ski resorts, including the Mount Omurga Ski Resort, which offers a range of amenities and services, including ski rentals, lessons, and accommodations.

Armorial of Albania

The Armorial of Albania refers to the collection of coats of arms, crests, and other heraldic symbols used by the various noble families, kingdoms, and states that have existed throughout Albania's history. The use of heraldic symbols in Albania dates back to the medieval period, and the country's complex history has resulted in a diverse and rich array of armorial bearings.

# Medieval period

During the medieval period, Albania was influenced by various European powers, including the Byzantine Empire, the Kingdom of Serbia, and the Republic of Venice. This period saw the emergence of several noble families and kingdoms that used heraldic symbols to identify themselves.

## Ambiguitatem

The earliest known use of heraldic symbols in Albania dates back to the 12th century, during the reign of the Byzantine Emperor Manuel I Komnenos. The emperor's seal featured a double-headed eagle, which would later become a popular symbol in Albanian heraldry.

## Regnum Albaniæ

In 1272, the Kingdom of Albania was established by Charles I of Anjou, who used a coat of arms featuring a shield with a red field and a white cross. This design was later adopted by the Albanian nobility and became a symbol of the kingdom.

## Feudal lords

During the medieval period, Albania was divided into several feudal lordships, each with its own coat of arms. The most prominent of these lordships were the Muzaka, the Kastrioti, and the Arianiti. The Muzaka family used a coat of arms featuring a shield with a blue field and a white eagle, while the Kastrioti family used a coat of arms featuring a shield with a red field and a black eagle.

# Albanian nobility

The Albanian nobility played a significant role in the country's history, and many noble families used heraldic symbols to identify themselves. The nobility was influenced by various European powers, including Austria-Hungary, Italy, and the Ottoman Empire.

### Dicio Pontificia

The Papal States, also known as Dicio Pontificia, had a significant influence on Albanian heraldry. Many Albanian noble families adopted Papal-style coats of arms, featuring shields with intricate designs and crests.

## Moldavia & Romania

Moldavia and Romania had a significant influence on Albanian heraldry, particularly during the 18th and 19th centuries. Many Albanian noble families adopted Moldavian- and Romanian-style coats of arms, featuring shields with intricate designs and crests.

Greece had a significant influence on Albanian heraldry, particularly during the 19th century. Many Albanian noble families adopted Greek-style coats of arms, featuring shields with simple designs and crests.

### Grand viziers

Egypt had a significant influence on Albanian heraldry, particularly during the 19th century. Many Albanian noble families adopted Egyptian-style coats of arms, featuring shields with simple designs and crests.

# Modern period

The modern period saw the emergence of a new Albanian state, which adopted its own system of heraldry. The new state used a coat of arms featuring a shield with a red field and a black eagle.

The Albanian Orthodox Church and the Albanian Catholic Church have their own systems of heraldry. The Orthodox Church uses a coat of arms featuring a shield with a blue field and a gold cross, while the Catholic Church uses a coat of arms featuring a shield with a red field and a gold cross.

Ole Miss riot of 1962

The Ole Miss riot of 1962 was a violent confrontation between federal authorities and rioting students and civilians that occurred on the University of Mississippi (Ole Miss) campus in Oxford, Mississippi, on September 30, 1962. The riot was sparked by the attempted enrollment of James Meredith, an African American student, at the previously all-white university. The event marked a significant turning point in the Civil Rights Movement and led to a major escalation of federal involvement in the desegregation of institutions of higher learning in the United States.

# Leadup

## Meredith's attempts to enroll

James Meredith, a 29-year-old African American veteran of the United States Air Force, had been attempting to enroll at Ole Miss since January 1961. Despite meeting all the necessary qualifications, Meredith was repeatedly denied admission due to his race. Meredith filed a lawsuit against the university, which ultimately made its way to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. On September 10, 1962, the court ordered Ole Miss to admit Meredith, but the university's board of trustees refused to comply.

## Kennedy dialogue and escalating tensions

In the days leading up to the planned enrollment, tensions escalated between the federal government and the state of Mississippi. President John F. Kennedy, who had been in communication with Mississippi Governor Ross Barnett, urged the governor to comply with the court order. Barnett, however, refused, citing concerns about the potential for violence and the need to protect the state's sovereignty. The dialogue between Kennedy and Barnett was tense, with Kennedy eventually threatening to use federal troops to enforce the court order if necessary.

article:
Speak Now (Taylor's Version)
==========================

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) is the re-recorded version of American singer-songwriter Taylor Swift's third studio album, Speak Now (2010). The album was released on July 7, 2023, through Republic Records. The re-recording of the album is part of Swift's effort to regain control over her master recordings after a highly publicized dispute with her former record label, Big Machine Records.

Background
----------

In June 2019, it was announced that Scooter Braun's company, Ithaca Holdings, had acquired Big Machine Records, Swift's former record label, for $300 million. As a result, Braun's company acquired the master recordings of Swift's music catalog from her first six studio albums, including Speak Now. Swift publicly expressed her disapproval of the deal, stating that she had not been given the opportunity to purchase her master recordings herself and that Braun's acquisition of her music was a "worst-case scenario" for her.

In August 2020, Swift announced that she would be re-recording her old albums in an effort to regain control over her master recordings. She stated that she planned to re-record all of her albums that were originally released under Big Machine Records, including Speak Now. The re-recording of Speak Now was officially announced on May 5, 2023, along with the album's tracklist and release date.

Music and lyrics
----------------

### Composition

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) features the same 14 tracks as the original album, as well as six additional "From the Vault" tracks that were written and recorded during the same period as the original album but were not included on the final tracklist. The album's musical style is a mix of country, pop, and rock influences, with lyrics that focus on themes of love, heartbreak, and self-empowerment.

The album's production is handled by Swift, along with producers Jack Antonoff and Aaron Dessner. The album features a more stripped-back and acoustic sound than some of Swift's other work, with a focus on showcasing her vocal and songwriting abilities.

### "From the Vault" tracks

The six "From the Vault" tracks included on Speak Now (Taylor's Version) are "You All Over Me", "Mr. Perfectly Fine", "We Were Happy", "That's When", "Don't You", and "I Can See You". These tracks were written and recorded during the same period as the original album but were not included on the final tracklist.

The "From the Vault" tracks offer a glimpse into Swift's songwriting process during this period and provide additional insight into her creative vision for the album. The tracks are notable for their raw, emotional quality and their focus on themes of love and heartbreak.

Release
--------

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) was released on July 7, 2023, through Republic Records. The album was made available on all major streaming platforms, including Spotify, Apple Music, and Amazon Music. Physical copies of the album, including CD and vinyl editions, were also released.

The album's release was accompanied by a social media campaign, with Swift sharing behind-the-scenes glimpses of the recording process and interacting with fans on Twitter and Instagram.

Critical reception
-----------------

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) received widespread critical acclaim upon its release, with many critics praising Swift's vocal and songwriting abilities. The album was noted for its raw, emotional quality and its focus on themes of love and heartbreak.

Commercial performance
---------------------

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) was a commercial success, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart and selling over 100,000 copies in its first week. The album also reached number one on the UK Albums Chart and the Australian Albums Chart.

Recognition
-----------

Speak Now (Taylor's Version) was recognized as one of the best albums of 2023 by several publications, including Rolling Stone and NME.

article:
2022 Missile Explosion in Poland

On November 15, 2022, a missile explosion occurred in the village of Przewodów, Poland, near the border with Ukraine. The incident happened during the Russian invasion of Ukraine, which had started in February 2022. The explosion killed two people and sparked a diplomatic crisis between Poland, Russia, and Ukraine.

#Background

The Russian invasion of Ukraine had been ongoing for nine months prior to the incident. The conflict had resulted in significant military and civilian losses on both sides. The Ukrainian military had been using various missile systems to defend against Russian attacks, while Russia had been conducting missile strikes against Ukrainian cities and military targets.

Poland, a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), had been providing military and humanitarian aid to Ukraine since the start of the conflict. The country had also been hosting thousands of Ukrainian refugees fleeing the war.

#Explosion

On November 15, 2022, at around 3:40 pm local time, a missile exploded in the village of Przewodów, Poland. The village is located in the Lublin Voivodeship, near the border with Ukraine. The explosion killed two Polish citizens, Bogusław Wos and Bogdan Wos, who were working at a grain drying facility.

The explosion was initially attributed to a Russian missile strike, but subsequent investigations suggested that the missile may have been of Ukrainian origin. The incident sparked a diplomatic crisis between Poland, Russia, and Ukraine.

#Investigation

The Polish government launched an investigation into the incident, with assistance from NATO and Ukrainian experts. The investigation focused on determining the origin and type of the missile, as well as the circumstances surrounding the explosion.

Initial reports suggested that the missile was a Russian Kh-101 or Kh-555 missile, but subsequent investigations suggested that it may have been a Ukrainian S-300 missile. The S-300 is a surface-to-air missile system used by the Ukrainian military to defend against Russian air attacks.

The investigation also examined the possibility that the missile was launched by Ukrainian forces in response to a Russian air attack. The Ukrainian military had been using the S-300 system to defend against Russian missile strikes, and it was possible that the missile had been launched in response to a Russian attack.

#Reactions

##Poland

The Polish government condemned the incident and called for an immediate investigation. Polish President Andrzej Duda stated that the incident was a "serious escalation" of the conflict and called for calm. The Polish government also increased military presence along the border with Ukraine.

##International

###Russia

The Russian government denied any involvement in the incident, stating that the missile was not of Russian origin. Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that the incident was a "provocation" aimed at escalating the conflict. The Russian government also accused Ukraine of launching the missile.

###Ukraine

The Ukrainian government denied any involvement in the incident, stating that the missile was not launched by Ukrainian forces. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy stated that the incident was a "tragedy" and called for an immediate investigation. The Ukrainian government also accused Russia of launching the missile.

###NATO officials and member countries

NATO officials condemned the incident and called for an immediate investigation. NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg stated that the incident was a "serious escalation" of the conflict and called for calm. NATO member countries, including the United States, Germany, and France, also condemned the incident and called for an investigation.

###Others

Other countries, including the United Kingdom, Canada, and Australia, also condemned the incident and called for an investigation. The European Union also condemned the incident and called for an investigation.

#Related incidents

The 2022 missile explosion in Poland was not an isolated incident. There have been several other incidents involving missile strikes and explosions near the border between Poland and Ukraine.

In October 2022, a Ukrainian S-300 missile exploded in the Ukrainian city of Mykolaiv, killing several people. The incident was attributed to a Russian air attack, and the Ukrainian military had launched the S-300 missile in response.

In November 2022, a Russian missile strike hit the Ukrainian city of Kherson, killing several people. The incident was condemned by the international community, and the Ukrainian military vowed to defend against further Russian attacks.

* Poland-Ukraine relations
* Russia-Ukraine relations

================

Kokshetau is a city located in the northern part of Kazakhstan, serving as the administrative center of Akmola Region. The city has a rich history dating back to the 19th century and has undergone significant transformations throughout the years. Today, Kokshetau is an important cultural, economic, and educational hub in the region.

Names and Etymology
--------------------

### Chronology of Name Changes

The city was founded in 1824 as Kokchetav, which is derived from the Kazakh words "kok" meaning "blue" and "chetav" meaning "mountain". In 1868, the city was renamed Kokchetavsk, and in 1993, it was renamed Kokshetau, which is the current name.

Physical Geography and Geology
-----------------------------

### Location

Kokshetau is situated in the northern part of Kazakhstan, approximately 300 kilometers north of the capital city Astana. The city is located in the Akmola Region, which is known for its fertile soil and abundant natural resources.

### Time

### Climate

The city has a humid continental climate with cold winters and warm summers. The average temperature in January, the coldest month, is around -15°C, while the average temperature in July, the warmest month, is around 20°C.

2022–23 Australian region cyclone season

The 2022–23 Australian region cyclone season is the period of the year when most tropical cyclones form in the Southern Indian Ocean and the southern Pacific Ocean, within the area bounded by 90°E and 160°E, south of the equator. The season officially runs from 1 November 2022 to 30 April 2023, although tropical cyclones can occur outside of this period.

#Season forecasts

In October 2022, the Australian Bureau of Meteorology (BOM) issued its forecast for the upcoming cyclone season, predicting a near-average season with 11 tropical cyclones expected to form in the region. The forecast also noted that there was a moderate to high chance of above-average cyclone activity in the western and eastern parts of the region.

The BOM also issued a forecast for the number of severe tropical cyclones (Category 3 or higher) expected to form in the region, predicting 4-6 severe cyclones. This forecast was based on the latest climate models and historical trends.

#Season summary

The 2022-23 Australian region cyclone season was marked by above-average activity, with a total of 15 tropical cyclones forming in the region. This was above the BOM's forecast of 11 tropical cyclones.

The season was also notable for the number of severe tropical cyclones that formed, with 6 severe cyclones occurring. This was above the BOM's forecast of 4-6 severe cyclones.

The strongest cyclone of the season was Severe Tropical Cyclone Freddy, which reached Category 5 strength on the Australian tropical cyclone intensity scale.

#Systems

##Tropical Cyclone 01U

Tropical Cyclone 01U was the first tropical cyclone of the season, forming on 1 November 2022 in the northwestern part of the region. The system moved westwards and dissipated on 5 November without affecting any land.

##Tropical Low 02U

Tropical Low 02U was a tropical low that formed on 10 November 2022 in the eastern part of the region. The system moved eastwards and dissipated on 14 November without affecting any land.

##Severe Tropical Cyclone Darian

Severe Tropical Cyclone Darian was a severe tropical cyclone that formed on 15 November 2022 in the western part of the region. The system moved southwards and intensified into a Category 5 cyclone on the Australian tropical cyclone intensity scale. Darian affected the coast of Western Australia, causing significant damage and disruptions.

##Tropical Cyclone Ellie

Tropical Cyclone Ellie was a tropical cyclone that formed on 22 November 2022 in the eastern part of the region. The system moved eastwards and dissipated on 27 November without affecting any land.

##Tropical Low 07U (Hale)

Tropical Low 07U was a tropical low that formed on 30 November 2022 in the western part of the region. The system moved westwards and dissipated on 5 December without affecting any land.

##Tropical Low 10U

Tropical Low 10U was a tropical low that formed on 15 December 2022 in the eastern part of the region. The system moved eastwards and dissipated on 20 December without affecting any land.

##Tropical Low 11U (Dingani)

Tropical Low 11U was a tropical low that formed on 20 December 2022 in the western part of the region. The system moved westwards and dissipated on 25 December without affecting any land.

##Tropical Low 12U

Tropical Low 12U was a tropical low that formed on 25 December 2022 in the eastern part of the region. The system moved eastwards and dissipated on 30 December without affecting any land.

##Severe Tropical Cyclone Freddy

Severe Tropical Cyclone Freddy was a severe tropical cyclone that formed on 30 December 2022 in the western part of the region. The system moved southwards and intensified into a Category 5 cyclone on the Australian tropical cyclone intensity scale. Freddy affected the coast of Western Australia, causing significant damage and disruptions.

##Severe Tropical Cyclone Gabrielle

Severe Tropical Cyclone Gabrielle was a severe tropical cyclone that formed on 5 January 2023 in the eastern part of the region. The system moved eastwards and intensified into a Category 4 cyclone on the Australian tropical cyclone intensity scale. Gabrielle affected the coast of New South Wales, causing significant damage and disruptions.

##Tropical Low 15U

Tropical Low 15U was a tropical low that formed on 15 January 2023 in the western part of the region. The system moved westwards and dissipated on 20 January without affecting any land.

##Tropical Low 16U

Tropical Low 16U was a tropical low that formed on 20 January 2023 in the eastern part of the region. The system moved eastwards and dissipated on 25 January without affecting any land.

##Tropical Low 17U

Tropical Low 17U was a tropical low that formed on 25 January 2023 in the western part of the region. The system moved westwards and dissipated on 30 January without affecting any land.

##Tropical Low 18U (Kevin)

Tropical Low 18U was a tropical low that formed on 30 January 2023 in the eastern part of the region. The system moved eastwards and dissipated on 4 February without affecting any land.

##Tropical Low 20U

Tropical Low 20U was a tropical low that formed on 10 February 2023 in the western part of the region. The system moved westwards and dissipated on 15 February without affecting any land.

##Severe Tropical Cyclone Herman

Severe Tropical Cyclone Herman was a severe tropical cyclone that formed on 15 February 2023 in the eastern part of the region. The system moved eastwards and intensified into a Category 4 cyclone on the Australian tropical cyclone intensity scale. Herman affected the coast of Queensland, causing significant damage and disruptions.

##Tropical Low 22U

Tropical Low 22U was a tropical low that formed on 20 February 2023 in the western part of the region. The system moved westwards and dissipated on 25 February without affecting any land.

##Severe Tropical Cyclone Ilsa

Severe Tropical Cyclone Ilsa was a severe tropical cyclone that formed on 25 February 2023 in the eastern part of the region. The system moved eastwards and intensified into a Category 4 cyclone on the Australian tropical cyclone intensity scale. Ilsa affected the coast of New South Wales, causing significant damage and disruptions.

##Other systems

There were several other tropical lows and tropical cyclones that formed in the region during the 2022-23 season, but did not affect any land.

#Storm names

The Bureau of Meteorology (BOM) is responsible for naming tropical cyclones in the Australian region. The BOM uses a list of names that are assigned to tropical cyclones in alphabetical order.

###TCWC Jakarta

The Tropical Cyclone Warning Centre (TCWC) Jakarta is responsible for naming tropical cyclones in the Indonesian region. TCWC Jakarta uses a list of names that are assigned to tropical cyclones in alphabetical order.

Sacré-Cœur, Paris

The Basilique du Sacré-Cœur, commonly known as Sacré-Cœur, is a Catholic basilica located in the 18th arrondissement of Paris, France. Perched on the hill of Montmartre, the church is a prominent landmark of the city and a popular tourist destination. Its striking white domes and bell tower are visible from many parts of Paris, and its architecture is a unique blend of Romanesque and Byzantine styles.

# History

## Proposal

The idea of building a church on the hill of Montmartre dates back to the 19th century. In 1870, during the Franco-Prussian War, two French Catholics, Alexandre Legentil and Hubert Rohault de Fleury, made a vow to build a church dedicated to the Sacred Heart of Jesus if Paris was spared from destruction. After the war, the city was indeed spared, and Legentil and Rohault de Fleury began to make plans for the church.

## Site

The site chosen for the church was the hill of Montmartre, which offered a panoramic view of the city. The hill had a long history of spiritual significance, dating back to the Druids and the Romans. In the Middle Ages, it was the site of a Benedictine abbey, and later, a Jesuit seminary.

## Construction

Construction of the church began in 1875 and took nearly four decades to complete. The architect, Paul Abadie, designed the church in a Romanesque-Byzantine style, inspired by the churches of the Mediterranean region. The church was built using a innovative technique called "pneumatic caissoning," which allowed workers to excavate the foundations and build the structure without disrupting the surrounding neighborhood.

## Controversy over the church

The construction of Sacré-Cœur was not without controversy. Many Parisians saw the church as a symbol of Catholicism and the monarchy, which were seen as oppressive forces in France. The church was also criticized for its location on the hill of Montmartre, which was seen as a sacred site by many Parisians. Additionally, the church's design was seen as too ornate and too expensive, and many critics felt that the money could be better spent on more practical needs.

# Description

## Exterior

The exterior of Sacré-Cœur is striking, with its white domes and bell tower rising above the surrounding buildings. The church's facade is simple, with a large rose window and a small entrance. The domes are covered in white stone, and the bell tower is topped with a small cross.

## Interior

The interior of Sacré-Cœur is equally impressive, with a large nave and two smaller side aisles. The church is decorated with intricate mosaics, sculptures, and stained glass windows.

### The Triumph of the Sacred Heart of Jesus mosaic

One of the most striking features of Sacré-Cœur is the large mosaic that covers the ceiling of the apse. The mosaic, titled "The Triumph of the Sacred Heart of Jesus," depicts Jesus Christ surrounded by angels and saints. The mosaic is made up of thousands of small tiles, and is one of the largest mosaics in the world.

### Chapels

Sacré-Cœur has several chapels, each dedicated to a different saint or aspect of Catholicism. The chapels are decorated with intricate carvings, sculptures, and stained glass windows.

### Crypt

The crypt of Sacré-Cœur is a small, intimate space that is dedicated to the remains of several French saints. The crypt is decorated with simple stone carvings and a few stained glass windows.

## Art and decoration

Sacré-Cœur is renowned for its stunning art and decoration. The church is filled with intricate mosaics, sculptures, and stained glass windows, all of which were created by some of the most talented artists of the time.

### Stained glass

The stained glass windows of Sacré-Cœur are some of the most beautiful in the world. The windows depict scenes from the Bible, as well as images of saints and angels. The windows were created by several different artists, including the famous artist, Louis Comfort Tiffany.

### Sculpture

The sculptures of Sacré-Cœur are equally impressive, with intricate carvings and statues of saints and angels. The sculptures were created by several different artists, including the famous sculptor, Auguste Rodin.

## Grand organ

Sacré-Cœur has a large and impressive grand organ, which is used for concerts and services throughout the year. The organ was built by the famous organ builder, Aristide Cavaillé-Coll.

## Bells

The bells of Sacré-Cœur are some of the most beautiful in the world. The bells are made of bronze and are tuned to produce a rich, resonant sound. The bells are rung throughout the day, and are an important part of the church's tradition.

# Role in Catholicism

Sacré-Cœur plays an important role in Catholicism, both in France and around the world. The church is a popular pilgrimage site, and is visited by millions of people each year. The church is also an important center for Catholic education and outreach, with several schools and community programs.

# Access

Sacré-Cœur is located in the 18th arrondissement of Paris, and is easily accessible by public transportation. The closest metro station is Anvers, which is a short walk from the church.

# Copy in Martinique

article:
Don't Worry Darling

Don't Worry Darling is a 2022 American psychological thriller film directed by Olivia Wilde from a screenplay by Katie Silberman, based on a story by Silberman, Carey Van Dyke, and Shane Van Dyke. The film stars Florence Pugh, Harry Styles, Chris Pine, Gemma Chan, Nick Kroll, and Wilde.

#Plot
The film is set in the 1950s and follows the story of Alice Chambers (Florence Pugh), a housewife living in the utopian community of Victory, California. Her husband, Jack (Harry Styles), works for the community's leader, Frank (Chris Pine), who is developing a mysterious project called "The Victory Project." As Alice becomes increasingly unsettled by the strange occurrences in the community, she begins to question the true nature of Victory and the motivations of its leaders.

#Cast
The film features an ensemble cast, including:
* Florence Pugh as Alice Chambers
* Harry Styles as Jack Chambers
* Chris Pine as Frank
* Gemma Chan as Shelley
* Nick Kroll as Bill
* Olivia Wilde as Bunny
* Asif Ali as Peter
* Douglas Smith as Jeff
* Kate Berlant as Peg
* Sydney Chandler as Babs
* Timothy Simons as Dean
* Ari'el Stachel as Ted

#Production
##Development and writing
The screenplay was written by Katie Silberman, based on a story by Silberman, Carey Van Dyke, and Shane Van Dyke. The story was inspired by the 1950s utopian community of Levittown, New York, and the mysterious circumstances surrounding it. Olivia Wilde was brought on board to direct the film, and she worked closely with Silberman to develop the script.

##Casting
The cast was announced in July 2020, with Florence Pugh and Harry Styles attached to star. Chris Pine, Gemma Chan, and Nick Kroll were added to the cast in August 2020. Olivia Wilde also joined the cast, playing the role of Bunny.

##Filming
Principal photography began on October 20, 2020, in Los Angeles, California. The film was shot on location in various parts of California, including Palm Springs and Los Angeles. The production team built a large-scale set in the desert to create the utopian community of Victory.

##Alleged conflicts on set
There were reports of conflicts on set during filming, with some sources suggesting that Olivia Wilde and Harry Styles had a romantic relationship, which allegedly caused tension with Florence Pugh.

###Wilde and LaBeouf
Olivia Wilde was initially set to cast Shia LaBeouf in the role of Jack, but he dropped out of the project in August 2020. Wilde later stated that LaBeouf's departure was due to scheduling conflicts, but there were reports that LaBeouf had been fired from the project due to on-set behavior.

###Wilde and Pugh
There were also reports of tension between Olivia Wilde and Florence Pugh, with some sources suggesting that Pugh was unhappy with the way the film was being directed. Wilde denied the reports, stating that she and Pugh had a "wonderful" working relationship.

#Marketing
The film's marketing campaign began in May 2022, with the release of the first trailer. The trailer received widespread attention, with many praising the film's visuals and performances.

#Release
Don't Worry Darling was released in the United States on September 23, 2022, by Warner Bros. Pictures. The film received a wide release, playing in over 4,000 theaters.

#Reception
##Box office
The film grossed $19.4 million in its opening weekend, with a total worldwide gross of $87.7 million.

##Critical response
The film received mixed reviews from critics, with many praising the performances and visuals, but criticizing the storytelling and pacing. The film holds a 73% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 422 reviews, with an average rating of 6.4/10.

##Accolades
The film received several award nominations, including two Academy Award nominations for Best Costume Design and Best Production Design.

#Notes
Don't Worry Darling is Olivia Wilde's second feature film as a director, following her debut film Booksmart in 2019. The film's score was composed by John Powell, with a soundtrack featuring music by artists such as Billie Eilish and Lizzo.

Kumar Sanu is a renowned Indian playback singer, primarily active in the Bollywood film industry. With a career spanning over three decades, Sanu has sung over 20,000 songs in numerous languages, including Hindi, Bengali, Telugu, Tamil, Kannada, Oriya, and many more. He has worked with prominent music directors and composers, rendering his voice to some of the most iconic songs in Indian cinema.

# Hindi films songs

Kumar Sanu has sung an extensive number of songs in Hindi films, collaborating with notable music directors such as Anand-Milind, Nadeem-Shravan, and Jatin-Lalit. Some of his most popular Hindi film songs include:

article:
2023 XFL Season

The 2023 XFL season was the third season of the XFL, a professional American football league owned by Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, Dany Garcia, and Gerry Cardinale's RedBird Capital Partners. The season marked the return of the XFL after a two-year hiatus due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

# Background

The XFL was originally founded in 2001 by the World Wrestling Federation (WWF), now known as WWE, but folded after one season due to low ratings and financial losses. In 2020, the XFL was revived with a new ownership group and a revamped business model. The 2020 season was cut short due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but the league announced plans to return in 2023 with a new format and expanded roster.

# Teams

The 2023 XFL season featured eight teams, divided into two divisions:

* North Division:
	+ Seattle Sea Dragons
	+ St. Louis BattleHawks
	+ Vegas Vipers
	+ DC Defenders
* South Division:
	+ Houston Roughnecks
	+ Orlando Guardians
	+ Arlington Renegades
	+ San Antonio Brahmas

# Players

## Draft

The 2023 XFL draft took place on November 15, 2022, with each team selecting 30 players. The draft was conducted via a snake draft format, with the first overall pick going to the Seattle Sea Dragons.

## Compensation

Players in the XFL are paid a weekly salary, with veterans earning $5,000 per week and rookies earning $3,000 per week. Players also receive a signing bonus and can earn additional income through sponsorship deals and bonuses.

## Player movement

The XFL allows players to move between teams during the season, with teams able to sign free agents and make trades. Players can also be released by their teams and become free agents.

## Partnerships

The XFL has partnered with several organizations to provide opportunities for players to develop their skills and gain exposure.

### Indoor Football League

The XFL has a partnership with the Indoor Football League (IFL), which allows players to play in the IFL during the XFL's off-season.

### NFL Alumni Academy

The XFL has a partnership with the NFL Alumni Academy, which provides training and development opportunities for XFL players.

## Notable players

* Former NFL quarterback Ben DiNucci
* Former NFL running back Christine Michael
* Former NFL wide receiver Keenan Reynolds
* Former NFL defensive end Damontre Moore

# Coaches

## Coaching changes

Several teams made coaching changes during the off-season, including the Seattle Sea Dragons, who hired former NFL coach Jim Haslett as their head coach.

# Rule changes

The XFL has made several rule changes for the 2023 season, including the introduction of a "tap" rule, which allows players to tap the ball to the ground to end a play, rather than having to take a knee.

# Standings

The XFL standings are divided into two divisions, with the top two teams from each division qualifying for the playoffs.

# Season structure

## Preseason

The XFL preseason took place in January 2023, with each team playing two exhibition games.

## Regular season

The XFL regular season began on February 18, 2023, and ran for 10 weeks.

## Postseason

The XFL playoffs took place in April 2023, with the top two teams from each division competing in a single-elimination tournament.
